anchor.surface_text: Bye-law 9 provides that an employee may resign from the service of the respondent by giving one months numberice. holdings.text: The findings of the Industrial Tribunal that the respondent refused to implement the award or decision by not taking the appellant back in service and that the appellant did not fail to resume duty or forfeit his right are upheld.

anchor.surface_text: The two questions of fact, viz., (i) whether the respondent refused to implement the award by not taking .the appellant back in service and (ii) whether it was the appellant who had failed to resume his duty in spite

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court perused correspondence between parties and found no reason to disturb lower tribunal's findings after due consideration.

holdings.text: The respondent cannot avail of the circumstances of transfer of business to Punjab National Bank Ltd. and closure of branches to reduce the value of reinstatement benefit.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that these circumstances cannot be availed of by the respondent. It is not doubt true that the respond- ent transferred its liabilities and equivalent assets to the

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not pleaded in written statement; correspondence shows respondent insisted on appellant joining at Delhi and never claimed inability to reinstate.

holdings.text: The computation of money value of reinstatement benefit under s.20(2) cannot be by analogy to measure of damages under s.95 Code of Civil Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal computed the money value of this benefit on the analogy of s. 95 of the Code of Civil Proce- dure. It treated the non-implementation of the direction in the

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even treating direction as statutory obligation, s.95 not appropriate measure for compensation; conceded by respondent's counsel.

holdings.text: The monetary value of reinstatement benefit is not to be computed as damages for breach of contract, wrongful dismissal, or tort.

anchor.surface_text: The benefit of reinstatement which is awarded to a workman under the terms of the award does not become a term or condition of the contract between him and the employer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reinstatement sets aside wrongful dismissal and continues original contract terms without variation; s.20(2) computes value of awarded benefit, not damages.

holdings.text: The prior finding of unfair labour practice and victimization precludes the respondent from terminating the appellant's service by mere one month's notice or pay in lieu.

anchor.surface_text: There was however a finding recorded by the Industrial Tribunal which made the award dated December 5, 1950, that the respondent had been guilty of unfair labour prac- tice

holdings.reasoning_summary: Finding deprives employer of ordinary termination right; future disputes would invite scrutiny by tribunal.

holdings.text: Under s.20(2), the money value of reinstatement benefit is computed by the tribunal having regard to all circumstances including terms of employment, tenure, termination possibilities, retrenchment, superannuation, mitigation, and future disputes.

anchor.surface_text: Such computation has relation only to the date from which the reinstatement of the workman has been ordered under the terms of the award and would have to be made by the Industrial

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation of s.20(2): determines value of non-monetary benefit for recovery; considers factors like in contract cases but for statutory benefit.

holdings.text: The benefit of reinstatement is reasonably computed at Rs. 12,500.

anchor.surface_text: we have come to the conclusion that having regard to all the circumstances of the case it would be reasonable to compute the benefit of reinstatement which was awarded to the appel-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Estimate after considering all relevant factors pro and con, including bye-laws, age, unfair practice finding, without mathematical exactitude.

precedents.citation: Collier v. Sunday Referee Publishing Co., Ltd. [1]

anchor.surface_text: Vide Collier v. Sunday Referee Publishing Co., Ltd. [1] . The servant would then be entitled to the whole of the salary, benefits, etc., which he would have earned had be continued in the employ of the master for the full 1 1940 4 All E.R. 237. term of the

precedents.case_name: Collier v. Sunday Referee Publishing Co., Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: damages for wrongful dismissal under fixed term employment contract
precedents.cited_holding: The servant would then be entitled to the whole of the salary, benefits, etc., which he would have earned had he continued in the employ of the master for the full term of the contract, subject of course to mitigation of damages by way of seeking alternative employment

precedents.citation: Salt v. Power Plant Co., Ltd. [1]

anchor.surface_text: Greer, J., in Salt v. Power Plant Co., Ltd. [1] are apposite in this context This is the case of a man who had, according to my view, got an engagement which was to last for life, or at any rate for the joint lives of himself and the company, but I think for his life, because, I think there are authorities to the effect that if a company winds up, that is a dismissal of the servants, and they can then prove for damages and get their dividend, whatever it may happen to be. Fortunately, the company has not been wound up, but in estimating the damages, of course, the tribunal estimating them will have to take into consideration the fact that at any time after June 26, 1935, it might have appeared to the directors that they had good reasons for terminating the plaintiffs serv-

precedents.case_name: Salt v. Power Plant Co., Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: considerations for estimating damages in case of life employment contract
precedents.cited_holding: in estimating the damages... the tribunal estimating them will have to take into consideration the fact that at any time... it might have appeared to the directors that they had good reasons for terminating the plaintiffs services... The present value of what his salary would be for the rest of his life must also be considered, and there must also be taken into account the fact that he is a man who might at any time terminate his service by his life coming to an end

justification_sets.label: Section 95 Code of Civil Procedure support

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal and set aside the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Lucknow as well as the award made by the Central Government Industrial Tribunal, Calcutta and award that the appellant shall recover from the respondent the said sum of Rs. 12,500  Rupees twelve thousand and five hundred only  being the computation of the money value of the benefit of reinstatement awarded to him under the terms of the award of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal at Calcutta dated December 5, 1950.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; Labour Appellate Tribunal decision and Industrial Tribunal award set aside; Rs. 12,500 awarded to appellant as money value of reinstatement benefit.

Appellant shall recover Rs. 12,500 from the respondent
